chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Reform should aim to keep the Electoral College’s federal balance while making outcomes track voters more closely and reducing the over-focus on a few swing states. A workable compromise is to curb winner-take-all by encouraging proportional elector allocation with basic anti-gerrymandering protections, while also adopting a national backstop like the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact if enough states join. Pair either path with clear, nationwide minimum standards for registration, ballot access, tabulation transparency, audits, and automatic recount triggers so close elections are decided by rules everyone can see and accept.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform the Electoral College in ways that keep a meaningful state role and political stability, but make outcomes track voters more fairly and reduce winner-take-all distortions. A practical compromise is to move states toward proportional (or district-based) allocation of electors paired with strong, uniform national standards for ballot access, counting, audits, and clear recount triggers so close elections are handled consistently. For those who want an even closer match to the national popular will without an immediate constitutional amendment, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact can be considered alongside these safeguards.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should aim to keep a meaningful role for states and smaller communities while making outcomes track the voters more closely and reducing the “winner-take-all” incentive to focus on a few battlegrounds. A broad middle path is proportional allocation of electors within each state (paired with enforceable anti-gerrymandering rules if districts are used) and clear national baselines for ballot access, secure chain-of-custody, audits, and transparent recount triggers. If consensus grows beyond that, the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact can be considered as an additional step, but any change should prioritize trust, stability, and equal respect for every lawful vote.
